Do you remember any disputes in...

And then it was the same thing when GEC went to Attachie,
because the work was drying up.
And then because they wanted so much work, we was working a three, three day.
So we had to go up the door to sign on to make up our money.
So Alfa Resta, because we only had three days, we worked for three days.
I remember that.
And we had picket strikes, loads of strikes.
What were the strikes about then?
About money.
About money always?
Yes, always about money.
And then later about this three day thing?
Yeah, yeah, three days then after that.
Were you affected by the miners' strike as well in the 70s?
No, not really.
I do remember when we had, they were going to do a tip.
And we had a bit of a row.
That was a protest as well.

Was it the gas?

they decided to move it somewhere else.
I think it was the gasworks or something.
There was something, there was something else.
What happened with your disputes about money?
How were they resolved? Did you usually win and get them?
Yeah, yeah, mostly.
We had loads of meetings, all the meetings were in the canteen.
Loads of meetings.

I just listened to it all because I wasn't money.
It was just shout out, you know.
But they were usually resolved favourably for you then?
Yes.
We also had one or two then of hoax.
And at the time they were used to have bomb scares.

But because of it we were all afraid and we used to go home early.

Bomb in the factory.
And we always took home, there were quite a few of them there was.
Bomb scares, yeah.
Who was responsible for them then?
Don't know, don't know really.
It's a scary story.
Do you think, well you said you had a few little accidents.
Do you think the work was dangerous, you know?
No.
Well, when I first, I do remember when I was fifteen,
they put me on this job and I was really frightened of it.

when they put me in for radios, and it was the back of the radio it was.

But I remember it was 1964 and they didn't have no guards then.

and I had to put this thing now underneath the back of the radio.

And I was terrified.

you shouldn't be doing it, you're only 15.

they thought I was older than 15.

and they said, is my daughter not supposed to go on there,
because she's only 15.
Because I was underage too, wasn't it?

and I came off it, I didn't have to go on it anymore.

that was dangerous, because there was no guard or nothing on there.

And when I went on this other line, it was great.
They would go every Friday night, this woman on this line, she was doing a minibus.
Anybody that wanted to go on this minibus, well, on a Friday night, we'd go to the night clubbing.
So they did me a favour of going on this line, and I thought, great, this is it.
And they asked me if I'd like to go, and I said yes.
So I was going then, and made friends with them, better than the line I was on.
They weren't very nice, and one or two of them.
You know, in the old days, they were a bit bitchy and all that, you know.
Because I was quiet, they sort of made fun of me, you know.
But I went on to this other line, and it was great.
And where are we going tonight?
And are we going to Swansea tonight?
If I wasn't too tired, because sometimes I was tired in one word.

Tell me, did you used to have Christmas do's with the factory then? Did they used to put on, how did you celebrate Christmas?
What we used to do, no we didn't have a Christmas do.
What we used to do, the last day of all, we used to work in the morning and then after we used to have our dinner,
then after dinner then we'd all stop, the foreman and foreman didn't mind us stopping.
And they used to come round then, every line, the foreman on the line used to have a tin of chocolates,
qualities treat of roses, and they used to give us all sweets.
Right.
So anyway, and everybody used to bring drink in, we used to put it underneath the benches,
and then after dinner we used to bring our drink out, and then we'd be drinking, on the line like.
What did the management think of that then?
They didn't mind, as long as we'd done our work in the morning, they didn't mind us having a little drinking,
some of us used to get a bit of drink, and they used to have tinsel in their hair and acting silly and all that.
And I remember once, we had one of those huge bins, one of those big bins, big plastic bins, there was a big huge bin,
and there was one or two of the girls who used to have a few drinks.
They used to grab hold of, I remember he was a bloke he was, he was short bloke,
and they pushed him into this bin for a laugh, they'd come out in the bin, and they pushed him into the bin and they were all laughing, you know.
It was just a bit of fun, you know.
And he used to get up and he'd say, you know, it was just a bit of fun.
Some of us used to go home then, some of us, a lot of the people then, they used to go to the pub nearest in Irwin,
when we'd all meet so and so for a drink, we'd all meet in the pub after, and all the workers, and we'd all have a drink there, you know,
before going home, so I used to go home then, I never bothered.
But, that's about it, I think, you know.
What about holidays then? When did you have holidays?
We used to have two weeks off for Easter, and we'd have a week off for Whitson, and we'd have two weeks on our summer holiday.
It was what you call the miners.
It was the same as, it was the last week of July and the first week of August that was our holiday.
Yes.
And we used to go anywhere we'd like.
My father had a touring caravan at the time, and we used to go off then, and we used to go to Puthcol a lot.
So did you always want to deal with the family?
Yes, always with the family. We used to go to Puthcol, and we used to go to Tenby.
Never went abroad, nothing like that.
But, did go to Devon one year, you know.
My father had a car, we just used to go off in all places, say.
And always on a Sunday, we used to be miserable on a Sunday.
And of course, then everything was closed then, and we were all miserable.
My father said, come on, he said, we'll have early dinner, let's go off for a ride in the car.
So we used to have early dinner.
And then we used to go past the seaside, or past we got bread and bread, or just for a ride in the car, to get us out to the emissary.

No.
No, right.

So tell me then, did you enjoy, on the whole, did you enjoy working in the factory?
Yes.
What about job satisfaction? Were you bored, or did you find it monotonous, or did you find the work okay?
I find that there were some jobs I went on that were harder than others.
On the majority, I enjoyed it there.
I did have that incident with that line, one or two of them girls, but everybody else had that.
But on the whole, there were great times, and I really, really enjoyed it.
So apart from that incident, how did you find the relationship with the women there, the camaraderie, that kind of thing?
Like I said, there's some women there, you get all kinds, you get some that are not very nice, they're bullyish then, if somebody was quiet then.
But apart from that one line, one or two of the girls were very nice, the majority at the time, I was okay, and they were quite friendly, they were nice.
Especially with that line I went on, and I went on nightclubs and everything with them, and it was great.
Did you make good friends there?
Yes, I made quite a lot of friends there.
So when did you decide to leave, and why did you leave?
I decided to leave because I was having my son, and I wasn't very well, so I could have gone on until I was nearly coming up to my time.
Sorry, what do you mean by your time?
When I was just about having John.
Oh the baby, sorry, yes I see.
Yes, when I was pregnant, and some to go on were they just about nearly, you know, about a month before I was born.
But I finished just after I was about two or three months, because I didn't feel very well, I felt sick and everything.
So I decided to finish a bit earlier, I went on to sit because I wasn't very well.
So how long did you work in the factory then?
Nearly 16 years I would say.
16 years, it's a long time.
Yes, 1964 to 1980, my son was born in 1980.
What did you do after, well you had a baby, but did you do any work after that, and did you ever work in a factory again?
I went back to GEC, I went to college, because my son was 16 then, and I had to come off job income support,
and I had to go on job seekers, because he was 16, he was older, and I had to start looking for work.
So I decided I wanted to do catering, because I used to love cooking and catering when I was in school.
I was always into cooking and doing catering and stuff.
So I decided to go to college, so as it happened I asked the dole if it was okay, and I was on what you call the New Deal.
When I first went there I was just doing part time, I had done once a week part time, up at college, doing the cooking.
Then when they said I can go on the New Deal, they said they will pay for me to go full time for a year.
So I decided then to go full time for a year to learn to get my NVQ, and I pastored it in my NVQ level 2 in catering hospitality.
So I had done that, and while I was in college you had to do work placement.
So you had to go somewhere in a kitchen to do placement, to learn how to do it.
So I had to do two, one was in Asdas, in the kitchen in Asdas, that was one placement, and I had to do it for two weeks.
I didn't get paid, but that was just a work placement.
My other one was you could go wherever you wanted, your choice.
So I decided I wanted to go at GC, right where I was attached, to go in the canteen there, and have a look around where I used to work.
So yes, they submitted it, I went there, and I went in the kitchen part day, I was having a look around, but it looked different because it was changed a bit.
They changed it around, so it did look a bit different when I was there.
So anyway, I went to the kitchen there, and when it was dinnertime the workers were coming in, because I was helping with the food, some of them knew me.
They said, oh hello, I haven't seen you for ages, and I said, what are you doing here?
I said, I'm doing catering now and all that.
He remembered me, they were still there, and it is great that he still remembered me from that time.
This was 2001.
So apart from that then, did you keep, when you left now, when you left, it was attached to you when you left, was it?
Yes.
So when you left, did you keep in touch with anybody from work?
No.
And looking back now then, how do you feel about the time you spent working in the factory?
I do often think back at the times, and sometimes, as it happened, the 60s and 70s were a great time for me, and I just enjoyed everything about it.
And as I said, every time it was good and bad, but I used to love the music and the fashion and everything that was at the time.
And it's because I was, as I was reminiscing, because in my youth I was young and everything, and I often think back, and I wish I had that time over again.
I'd love to go back to the 60s and 70s. If I had my wish, I'd love to go back there.
And what about going back to work in the factory? Would you go back again?
Yes, I wouldn't mind that at all.
It was great times, you know, but I got my memories, because things are going like that, and I got that wonderful feeling.
I didn't have it anymore, it was all just the sat-wenn world, but it was a great day.
That's great. Thank you very much for seeing.
